translation: Rise at the rooster's crow to practice swordplay
source: This idiom originates from the 'Book of Jin: Biographies of Zu Ti and Liu Kun'. It tells the story of two Jin Dynasty patriots, Zu Ti and Liu Kun, who were close friends and shared a deep concern for their troubled country. To prepare themselves to serve the nation, they would wake up and start practicing martial arts immediately upon hearing the rooster crow at dawn, demonstrating their determination and discipline.
meaning: It describes a person who is highly self-disciplined, diligent, and seizes the early morning hours to work hard towards their ambitions. It emphasizes the virtues of perseverance, making the most of one's time, and maintaining a strong will to achieve one's goals.
usage: This idiom is used in a positive and encouraging tone to praise someone's diligence, strong work ethic, and commitment to self-improvement. It is suitable for contexts related to studying, training, personal development, or pursuing long-term aspirations. It can be used as motivation or as a compliment.

source: This idiom originates from a story about Ji Kang, a famous scholar and musician from the Wei-Jin period. In 'A New Account of the Tales of the World' (《世说新语》), it is recorded that when people praised his son Ji Shao for being outstanding, Ji Kang humorously replied, 'I didn't realize he stood out so much among ordinary people, like a crane among chickens.' The phrase vividly captures the image of someone or something markedly superior to its surroundings.
meaning: It describes a person or thing that is exceptionally outstanding, distinguished, or superior compared to those around them. It highlights a striking contrast in quality, talent, or appearance within a group.
usage: Used to praise someone's exceptional abilities, qualities, or achievements that make them stand out positively in a group. It carries a complimentary and admiring tone. It is commonly applied in contexts describing people, works of art, performances, or any entity that is conspicuously better than its peers.

translation: to have a well-thought-out plan in mind
source: This idiom originates from a story about the Northern Song Dynasty painter Wen Tong. He was famous for painting bamboo, and before putting brush to paper, he would have a complete, vivid image of the bamboo in his mind. His contemporary, the poet and painter Su Shi, praised him in an essay, saying that Wen Tong succeeded because he already had the perfected bamboo in his heart before painting. This story was recorded in Su Shi's 'Collected Works of Su Dongpo'.
meaning: It means to have a well-thought-out plan or a clear idea before taking action. It describes someone who is fully prepared and confident because they have carefully considered all aspects of a situation in advance.
usage: Used to describe someone who is confident and prepared when facing a task, challenge, or decision. It has a positive and admiring tone, often applied in contexts like business, exams, presentations, or creative projects. For example, 'She walked into the negotiation room,胸有成竹, having prepared for every possible question.'

translation: A mantis trying to stop a chariot
source: This idiom originates from the ancient Chinese text 'Zhuangzi: The Human World' (庄子·人间世). It tells the story of a charioteer named Ju Boyu (遽伯玉) who advised the ruler of the state of Wei. He used the metaphor of a mantis angrily raising its forelegs to block an oncoming chariot, unaware of its own inability to accomplish such a feat, to warn against overestimating one's own strength and rashly confronting a far more powerful opponent.
meaning: It describes someone who overestimates their own abilities and foolishly attempts to resist a force or opponent that is overwhelmingly stronger, leading to inevitable failure. It warns against reckless defiance and highlights the importance of self-awareness and recognizing one's limitations.
usage: This idiom is used in a cautionary or slightly mocking tone to criticize unrealistic overconfidence and reckless actions against overwhelming odds. It is often applied in contexts like politics, business, sports, or personal conflicts. For example: 1) 'Trying to sue that giant corporation with your tiny startup is like a mantis trying to stop a chariot.' 2) 'His plan to challenge the reigning champion with just a month of training was nothing short of a mantis trying to stop a chariot.'
